snippet: The debate over the government’s role in creating opportunity and ending deprivation has flared anew, with inequality as acute as it was in the Roaring Twenties and the ranks of the poor and near-poor at record highs.
abstract: Washington Memo; debate over the government's role in creating opportunity and ending deprivation has flared anew, half a century after Pres Lyndon Johnson declared a war on poverty; although many Americans view the war on poverty as a failure, there is broad consensus that social welfare programs created since the New Deal have hugely improved living conditions for low-income Americans.
lead_paragraph: The debate over the government’s role in creating opportunity and ending deprivation has flared anew, with inequality as acute as it was in the Roaring Twenties and the ranks of the poor and near-poor at record highs.

headline.main: 50 Years Later, War on Poverty Is a Mixed Bag
headline.print_headline: 50 Years Later, War on Poverty Is a Mixed Bag
